segments.text: This is an interview with Lynn Bond, Lieutenant Colonel, United States Marine Corps, retired by Shannon Bond on April 3, 1993, at his home in Richardson, Texas, concerning his involvement in the Vietnam War.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge, I'm asking you to donate this tape to me or to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is that all right with you?
It's perfectly all right.
OK. Start out with, could you please
Tell us your date and place of birth.
I was born in Bullard, Texas, June the 18th, 1932.
And tell us about your educational background.
I attended grade school and high school in Bullard, and I graduated from Bullard High School in 1949 and joined the Marine Corps at that point.
I subsequently attended night school and obtained roughly two years of college in night school.
And that's the extent of my formal education.
OK. Why did you enlist in the Marine Corps to begin with?
I'm not really sure.
I think it was probably twofold.
One, at that time, we were about to enter into a depression type
economic period.
It was very hard to get a job.
I did not have good enough grades to get a scholarship to college and would have had a great deal of trouble supporting myself and paying for college at the same time.
So, one, I wanted to be covered under the GI Bill, which still was in force from World War II at that time, and
Secondly, I really didn't know what I wanted to do.
And so it was kind of on a lark that a friend of mine one day says, why don't we join the Marine Corps?
And so we went to Tyler, joined, was supposed to come back the next day to go to boot camp.
I came back.
He didn't.
So I wound up going by myself.
OK.
How did you wind up in Vietnam?
Well, I volunteered to go to Vietnam.
In 1967, I completed Amphibious Warfare School at Quantico, Virginia.
I was a major at that time.
And, well, it was the thing to do.
We were fairly
heavily engaged at that time, and it was being escalated, the number of forces that was going.
So I volunteered to go.
It's kind of academic.
They would have sent me sooner or later anyway, because the requirements for forces had reached the point where everybody was going to go sooner or later.
But I wanted to go.
I believed that what we were doing was just,
was right and of course I don't think you could be a good Marine or a good soldier and not want to be involved in whatever was going on with your country.
So I vowed there.
Okay.
Were you surprised by the Tet Offensive and why or why not?
Yes, very much so.
Just prior to the Tet Offensive,

My battalion, 2nd Battalion, 26 Marines, had responsibility for the Hue Phu Bai area and for the main road that led from, actually, I think it goes from well up in the North Vietnam all the way down to Saigon.
We had responsibility for about 50 kilometers of road
which included Hue Phu Bai, which is one of the major cities in, let's say, central Vietnam.
And there was not very much activity as far as the Viet Cong was concerned at that time.
But about three weeks before the Tet Offensive, my battalion was given orders to move up to the northeast
anchor on the DMZ, not on the DMZ, it's been so long now I'm having trouble remembering some of these places.
I had to, it was Hoang Song, it was a line that went across Vietnam which was known at that time as the McNamara Line.
And we were ordered up to that location
I took half of the battalion and started up there and just before we reached that point they changed our orders and sent us to Khe Sanh.
So actually I spent the entire Tet Offensive in Khe Sanh.
While the Tet Offensive was going on primarily in Hue Phu Bai and in Saigon, they also
made a major effort to capture Khe Sanh.

Now Khe Sanh is on the western part of Vietnam over near the Laotian border and so I spent the siege of Khe Sanh there but yes the activities around Hue Phu Bai which I was the most familiar with was very light and so the the Tet Offensive of 68
67, 68 came as quite a surprise to me.

Okay, you've already mentioned Khe Sanh and understand that the siege was just involved some very fierce fighting and there's been stories of conditions on the North Vietnamese side being so bad that they had to eat rats and things like that.
Tell me about Khe Sanh all that you can.
Well, I don't know anything about the
the Vietnamese portion of that.
First, I think you should realize that a person's views of any combat situation is very, very subjective.
My views is going to be different from anyone else's.
That doesn't make mine right, nor does it make the other people's wrong.
It is my personal opinion.
that there has been more pure garbage written about Vietnam than probably any other war that ever was fought.

I know we used to get reports and I would get letters and so forth about from home about how bad everything was in Khe Sanh and so forth and what all was going on about how the Vietnamese were tunneling under
our lines, and so on and so forth.
And it was pure hogwash.
The siege of Quezon was primarily a situation where they sat and pounded us with rockets and artillery for, oh, I don't know, 70 or 80 days, something along those lines.
And we did sit there and were pounded.
in a terrible way for this period of time.
But we were dug in.
Everybody was in trenches and bunkers that had overhead protection and that included runway matting with sand bags on top of it.
Generally speaking there was
very little need to get out of your bunker.
So we simply sat there.
And they simply fired their artillery and so forth.
The truth of the matter is, it was not extremely effective.
We had the 1st Battalion 9th Marines, the 3rd Battalion 26th Marines,
Well, 1st, 2nd, 3rd Battalion, the 26th Marines were all at Khe Sanh and reinforced by the 1st Battalion, 9th Marines.
There was also Army Special Forces there who had their positions actually set up outside of the Khe Sanh Combat Bay.
Now, a portion of the 2nd Battalion, 26th Marines
later left the combat base and went into a blocking position about five or six kilometers north of the base.
We also had a reinforced rifle company that was on a hill north, northwest of the base.
And the 3rd Battalion, 26 Marines, had a company that was on, I believe it was Hill 881, but I
I don't recall a lot of this.
Now, there were times when our units that were on the hills, 881 and I believe it was 812, their positions were attacked several times by some rather significant forces.
But the main combat base,
only had minor probes as far as infantry attacks on the base is concerned.
Everything else was just pure artillery and rocket attacks, which were quite severe for many, many days.
And so that was hard on the troops, but it really wasn't a big deal.
How many was out there?
I don't know.
They told us at varying times that there was probably as many as 50,000 North Vietnamese.
And these were North Vietnamese, not Viet Cong.
These were North Vietnamese troops.
But we had one battalion and one battery of artillery inside the combat base.
All of our other artillery support came from Camp Carroll, which was, oh, about 10, 15,000 meters away.
But we had all the air support that anyone could ever ask for to include B-29s, which we never asked for, but on several occasions were directed to use.
So we had to come up with targets for B-29s.

And when told that we really didn't have any targets for B-29, we were told to select them because LBJ, that's president, had said that he is going to do everything humanly possible to see to it that we were not overrun.
Now, they were indicating that it was imminent that the combat base would be overrun by the day.
We never felt that it would be.
They gave us intelligence reports at varying times that there would be an armored attack by the North Vietnamese.
And they tried to make it look like it was a lot worse than it really was.
Had there been an armored attack of any significance, we might have had a problem.
If my memory serves me correctly, we had a sum total of five tanks.
And other than that, each battalion had a 106 recoil-less rifle, platoon, and of course, each infantry company has 3.5 rockets, which are anti-tank weapons.
But a concerted armored attack.
And they could have indeed overrun the base because we had inadequate armor.
And if they selected to do this at a time when the air could not have been used, then they could have overrun the base.
Now, the weather up there at that time was such that often you could not use air until noon.
because of the fog and so forth.
But I think the severity of the action around Quezon, for the most part, other than the fact that they used their artillery to pound us for a long time, has probably been grossly overstated.
What impact do you feel that firepower had on the war?
Well, first of all, I assume you mean from both sides here.
We had superior firepower.
There's no question about it.
Except at that particular place and at that particular time.
They had amassed more rockets and artillery
than what we had.
As I indicated, the only artillery that we had was a reinforced artillery battalion.
It was a 105 battalion reinforced with one battery of 155 howitzers.
We could get 175 support from Camp Carroll.
Then everything else we got in the way of firepower had to be air.
This was at a time that our all-weather capability was not quite as good as a lot of people thought it was.
So during periods of reduced visibility, your air support was somewhat questionable.
And this was also before we started using our so-called smart bomb.
They were everything we used up until this point was dumb bombs.
And when you're using dumb bombs, you don't get anywhere near the effectiveness that a lot of people would have you believe.
But we, well, first of all, they had no air in South Vietnam.
To the best of my knowledge, they never used air against our infantry forces.
I know they didn't against us, and to the best of my knowledge, they never did against any US ground forces.
We had such vast air superiority that it was just no contest.
And we were able to use it quite effectively, but the Vietnamese soldier,
Totally different from the U.S. soldier.
He was not as well trained in many, many ways, but he was far more disciplined in that he would dig tunnels, he would dig trenches and so forth that would give him more protection.
And as a result,
you might think that you had done a tremendous amount of damage in an artillery barrage or in an airstrike, and come to find out, you really hadn't.
I mean, when the smoke cleared up and you'd go back into that area, you'd find that he's still there and was ready to fight.
But the firepower was the deciding factor in our
side of the thing.
But when they decided that they wanted to stay and fight, they could stay and fight with the best of them.
The oriental, not the oriental, yeah, I guess the oriental soldier is very, very disciplined.
And he will stay and do what he's told.
The Chinese communists in Korea were a lot like that.
They lost a lot of men, but losing a lot of men was no big deal to them.
You could wipe out a battalion and they'd simply send another battalion up and it didn't bother them.
They didn't have a situation where the mothers and fathers at home got upset and wouldn't support the government.
I doubt very seriously if a battalion commander had to write home and say, hey,
Your son has been killed.
Whereas we had to write in each navigation, we even had to tell how it happened.
But I'm getting off the beaten path.
But firepower was very, very important.
Were you optimistic about winning the war?
When you first arrived in Vietnam, why or why not?
Oh, yes.
I was optimistic.
We had vastly superior forces.
And at that time, what we were doing is we were confronting the Viet Cong.
We were, you know, this was before the North Vietnamese was involved in any significant extent.
I guess a lot of it was ego, but we like to believe that the little Viet Cong peasant soldier was no match for us, no match for our equipment, no match for our firepower.
They didn't have helicopters, for instance.
We could get in helicopters and move about as we saw fit.
If the Viet Cong wanted to move a force, they walked.
They didn't have trucks for all practical purposes.
And so yeah, I thought we could take care of it without any trouble.
And secondly, I thought that what was taught in military doctrine at the time was the way to defeat a guerrilla army is to
go into the area and to win the hearts and minds of the people in the area, and hence the guerrilla then had no base of support.
And that was really our major effort when I got there, was to go in and win the hearts and minds of the people.
And I thought we were doing a pretty good job of it, but apparently we were not, because
The Vietcong continued to increase their forces and then of course the North Vietnamese moved in to take over and then it was a different ballgame altogether.
What about when you left the war?
Well I left from Quezon and my
Initial judgment at that time was that they had lost quite a large force in that Tet Offensive.
And they had lost a lot of people in the Tet Offensive.
And I wondered if they had the will as a country, now I'm talking North Vietnam now, to continue to fight.
I guess what I should have been concerned about was whether or not we had the will as a country to continue to fight.
Because that was at the time when the anti-war forces back in the United States really started growing and started having an effect.
But I thought that we could still win the war, well I still believe we could have won
if as a nation we had a goal of winning rather than just a status quo.
So I believe that there was an error as far as a national goal is concerned in the Vietnam War.
The first time you were in Vietnam, you were only there for seven months.
Yeah.
Why was that?
Well, on the way to Vietnam, I was, we stopped on Okinawa, and they changed my orders.
A general that I had worked for back in Camp Lejeune saw my orders on the way through, and he had just moved there to
form Fleet Marine Force Pacific forward staff and was told, you can take anybody you see coming through and form your staff.
Well, he knew me.
And he pulled me off.
And all the begging and pleading and crying and so forth would not change his mind one iota.
But he did promise me that after six months, he would send me on into Vietnam, which
what he did and that's why it was for only seven months.
Okay.
Tell me your feelings about the anti-war movement.
Well, I think they were wrong.
You know, it's just that simple.
I'm not against people protesting.
I think that that's one of our basic rights.
And if you did not have the right to disagree with your government, then you would not have a true democracy.
I believe this all started, however, through a group of what were referred to then as hippies, which were really just anti-establishment.
They were against everything.

government was doing and it just happened that the government was involved in war and that just happened to be something that that they could could gather a lot of emotional support for i think most of the people involved in the the vietnamese war were doing so just because they they were against everything

And I think there's a distinct difference between having an honest disagreement with what your government is doing and exercising a right which I support to the fullest to disagree, and then just being disagreeable.
Now, it's hard to say the vast majority, but I will say this, that the vast majority of the leadership of the anti-war parties
our anti-war group, in my judgment, were totally and completely worthless people.
And I think it was wrong.
And even though they had the right to do it, it did cost many lives.
And it created an atmosphere in this country
that the truth of the matter is we're just now working our way out of it.
The Desert Storm Operation did a tremendous amount to reunite and refocus the unity of the country.
But up until that point,
They had been very successful in the anti-war environment that they had been able to create in this country.
And how do I feel about it?
I think it was absolutely terrible.
I mean, you take a Jane Fonda, for instance, who went to North Vietnam, had pictures made
of her on an anti-aircraft gun while US forces were flying combat missions over there and were being shot down by those very things.
I can't forgive her for that.
There is a perfectly acceptable dissent.
She passed way beyond that.
There are conscientious objectors.
No problem with them.
The vast majority of the people we're talking about though were not just conscientious objectors.
They were just objectors.
They objected to everything.
When I left Vietnam, I went to Washington.
And I got there after several of the big riots took place
much of which were caused by the anti-war demonstrators.
Part of it was civil rights, but the vast majority of this was not civil rights.
The vast majority of it evolved around the anti-war demonstrators.
ROTC armories, for instance, on college campuses weren't safe.
People were breaking into those.
They were stealing weapons.
They were burning them.
They were picketing around ROTCs, calling these young students killers, and so on and so forth.
They were terribly objective people.
And if I didn't feel so strongly about the basic rights and privileges
what we have here in America.
I would say, you know, let's exterminate these people.
But they have the right to do it.
And as objectionable as they are, in the final analysis, I truly believe that they were the very best advertisement for democracy

there has ever been anywhere in the world because in russia and china and other places where this is they they could look and see and say how in the world can that nation allow people to do this see that's the true definition of freedom when you have the freedom to do that then you've got real freedom
And like I say, had they been smart enough to know that they were democracy's best advertisement, they wouldn't have done it.
They wouldn't have done it.
And so I guess we have to give them a certain amount of credit for what we see throughout the world now.
Russia, Russian communism.
having gone down the tubes.
All the other European communistic countries having gone down the tubes.
The complete and total failure of communism throughout the world.
